\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town A } \\

\hline Yes & \( 39 \) \\
\hline No & \( 11 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} \( 200 \) people in Town B are asked if they eat meat. \begin{tabular}{|cc|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{ Town B } \\
\hline Do you eat meat? & Frequency \\
\hline Yes & \( 143 \) \\
\hline No & \( 57 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which results are more reliable?

![A graph with two curves. One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the y axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x axis.
The other curve is in the negative x, negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left close to the x axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the y axis then becomes almost vertical to travel almost parallel to the y axis. ]()

Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
AnswerAText: \( 82 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 27^{\text {th }} \) term
AnswerBText: \( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term
AnswerCText: \( 82 \) is not in the sequence because \( 27 \) is an integer
AnswerDText: Eliza's method does not answer this question

ConstructName: Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern
QuestionText: What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
AnswerAText: ![This pattern is the same as Pattern 4: it is made up of 9 squares as a 4 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerBText: ![This pattern is made up of 11 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerCText: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then 2 extra squares on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()
AnswerDText: ![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle, and one more square to the right of that one.]()

ConstructName: Describe a term-to-term sequence

Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
4, \quad 10, \quad 28, \quad 82, \quad \ldots
\]
AnswerAText: To get the next term you add \( 6 \) to the previous term
AnswerBText: To get the next term you add the previous two terms together
AnswerCText: To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)
AnswerDText: To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 3 \) and subtract \( 2 \)

ConstructName: Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division
QuestionText: This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
AnswerAText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 8 \) 
So the answer is \( 32 \)
AnswerBText:
There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)
AnswerCText:
There are \( 6 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 6 \) by \( 4 \) 
So the answer is \( 24 \)
AnswerDText:
There are \( 8 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \)
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)

ConstructName: Construct an angle of 60° using a ruler and a compass
QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct an angle of \( 60^{\circ} \) using a ruler and a pair of compasses?
AnswerAText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect 
- Bisect the angle created
AnswerBText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line
- Join up where the lines intersect
- Bisect the angle created
AnswerCText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect
AnswerDText:
- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Join up where the lines intersect

ConstructName: Calculate the mean from a frequency table
SubjectName: Averages and Range from Frequency Table

The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()

ConstructName: Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c
QuestionText: When factorising \( x^{2}+6 x+8 \) we need two numbers that:
AnswerAText: Add to give \( 6 \) and multiply to give \( 8 \)
AnswerBText: Add to give \( 6 x \) and multiply to give \( 8 \)
AnswerCText: Add to give \( 8 \) and multiply to give \( 6 \)
AnswerDText: Add to give \( 8 x \) and multiply to give \( 6 \)

ConstructName: Identify and represent sets using set notation
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing the probability spinner

Tom says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,2\} \)

Katie says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,1,2,2,2\} \)
Who do you agree with? ![Circle divided into 5 equal sections. 2 sections labelled with a blue number 1. 3 sections labelled with a red number 2.]()

ConstructName: Determine if a given point lies on a line
SubjectName: Plotting Lines from Tables of Values
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about points on the line
\[
y=2 x-3
\]

Tom says \( (5,7) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{3} \)

Katie says \( (-5,-7) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \)

Who is correct?

\)

ConstructName: Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c

Tom and Katie are arguing about factorising. Tom says \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \equiv(x+3)(x+2) \) 
Katie says \( x^{2}-5 x-6 \equiv(x-3)(x-2) \) 
Who is correct?

ConstructName: Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![The first 3 patterns in a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a blue rectangle with 6 yellow circles attached to its perimeter: 2 circles on each of the longer sides and 1 circle on each of the shorter sides. 
Pattern 2 is made up of 2 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle). 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 14 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to another rectangle).]() Tom says the number of circles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of circles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Katie says the number of rectangles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of rectangles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?

ConstructName: Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio
QuestionText:
Tom and Katie are arguing about the information on the right.

Tom says there are \( 9 \) times as many students as teachers.

Katie says one in ten people are teachers.
Who is correct? On a school trip, the ratio of teachers to students is:
teachers : students
\(
1: 9
\)

ConstructName: Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication
QuestionText: Which working out is correct for $72 \times 36$?
AnswerAText: ![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with incorrect working and incorrect final answer. First row of working is incorrect: 4 2 2. Second row of working is incorrect: 2 7. Final answer is incorrect: 4 4 9.]()
AnswerBText: ![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with incorrect working and incorrect final answer. First row of working is correct: 4 3 2. Second row of working is incorrect: 2 1 6. Final answer is incorrect: 6 4 8.]()
AnswerCText: ![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with correct working and incorrect final answer. First row of working is correct: 4 3 2. Second row of working is correct: 2 1 6 0. Final answer is incorrect: 2 7 0 0.]()
AnswerDText: ![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with correct working and correct final answer. First row of working is correct: 4 3 2. Second row of working is correct: 2 1 6 0. Final answer is correct: 2 5 9 2.]()

AnswerDText: ![128 multiplied by 26 set out to perform long multiplication. 26 is written under 128. The 2 of 26 is under the 2 of 128 and the 6 of 26 is under the 8 of 128.]()

ConstructName: Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle
QuestionText: Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
AnswerAText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw a line \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) long that starts at the same end of the line and goes through the dot.
- Join up the end of this line with the other end of the \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) line.
AnswerBText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Set the compass width to \( 40 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from one end of the line
- Set the compass width to \( 50 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from the other end of the line
- Join up the ends of the line to the intersection of the arcs with straight lines
AnswerCText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle
AnswerDText:
- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

ConstructName: Translating word problems into linear algebraic equations
QuestionText: A bakery is having a sale on bread. A regular loaf of bread normally costs $2.50, and a whole wheat loaf costs $3.00. If Sara buys 2 regular loaves and some whole wheat loaves for a total of $13.50, how many whole wheat loaves did she buy? Let x be the number of whole wheat loaves.
AnswerAText: 2x + 2 * 2.50 = 13.50, 2x + 5.00 = 13.50, 2x = 8.50, x = 4.25, x is rounded down to 4 because Sara can't buy part of a loaf, x = 4 loaves
AnswerBText: 4 * 2.50 = 13.50 - 5.00, 4 * 2.50 = 8.50, 10 = 8.50, x = no solution because 4 * 2.50 is not equal to 8.50 then let x equal to 3, 3 * 3.00 = 9.00, 2 * 2.50 = 5.00, 9.00 + 5.00 = $14.00 then try x = 2, 2 * 3.00 = 6.00, 2 * 2.50 = 5.00, 6.00 + 5.00 = $11.00 then try x = 3 but this is incorrect because the total is 14.00 instead of 11.00 and x must be higher than 3 because the actual total is 13.50 instead of 14.00 or 11.00, try x = 3 again, we were originally correct because Sara can't buy part of a loaf,  4 * 2.50 is not equal to 8.50 we can simplify this to x * 3.00, 3 * x = x  = 8.50 / 3 = 2.8333 round down to 2.
MisconceptionName: Cannot spot a variable within a written scenario

ConstructName: Solve simultaneous linear equations using the method of substitution or elimination
QuestionText:
Solve the system of equations: 
x + 3y = 7 
2x - 2y = 6
AnswerAText:
First, multiply the second equation by 1 and the first by -2 to make the x terms in both equations opposite. 
-2x - 6y = -14 
2x - 2y = 6 
Adding the equations gives -8y = -8. 
Divide both sides by -8 to get y = 1. 
Substitute y = 1 into the first equation x + 3(1) = 7 
x + 3 = 7 
x = 4
AnswerBText:
First, add x + 3y = 7 and 2x - 2y = 6, since the y terms are similar looking. 
3x + y = 13 
Subtract 2x - 2y = 6 from the new equation: 
(3x - 2x) + (y + 2y) = (13 - 6) 
x + 3y = 7, now substitute x + 3y = 7 into the new equation, leading to 3y = 7 - y, leading to many incorrect paths 
Eventually may assume x = 2, y = 2
MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they can add variables to one of the equations to make terms across the 2 equations identical

ConstructName: Add surds by combining like terms

MisconceptionName: Multiplies surds when asked to add

ConstructName: Interpret Cumulative Frequency Graphs
QuestionText:
The following cumulative frequency graph represents exam scores. What is the score below which 60% of students scored.


Cumulative Frequency Graph: 
 Scores on x-axis: 0 - 10, 11 - 20, 21 - 30, 31 - 40 
 Cumulative Frequencies: 20, 40, 70, 100 


 What is the score below which 60 students scored.
(X students in total  100)
AnswerAText: 20, as 60% of 100 is 60, and on the graph the 60th student corresponds to scores of up to 20
AnswerBText: 7.5 since 20% of 100 is below 0 - 10 and 40% is below 11 - 20, therefore the 60th student is below 11 - 20, but to find the exact point, the midpoint of the 0 - 10 and the 11 - 20 class ranges are evaluated as 7.5 for the first and 15.5 for the second range,  the 20% score 7.5 and the 40% score 15.5 and hence the 60% cumulative frequency is found plotting the points, drawing line and the extrapoating and evaluating a value of  7.5 (first class range). Extra extrapolation is done from -3rd class lower than 0-10, but not necessary
MisconceptionName: Believes cumulative frequency is plotted at the lower bound of the class

ConstructName: Divide both sides of an algebraic equation by the same amount to solve for a variable

AnswerBText: x = 12 ÷ 3 and the term 3 is not changed, so x + 3 (the term 3 stays on the left) = 12 ÷ 3, x = 4 - 3. Thus, x = 4.</Correct Answer>
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that when dividing both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be divided by the same amount

QuestionText: A rectangular cuboid has a length of 5cm, a width of 3cm, and a height of 4cm. Find the length of the space diagonal.
MisconceptionName: Believes the space diagonal is the same length as the diagonal on the bottom face of a cuboid

ConstructName: Interpret and explain the interquartile range (IQR) in a given set of data
QuestionText: A dataset contains the following values: 4, 6, 8, 11, 13. What is the interquartile range (IQR) if the first quartile (Q1) is 6 and the third quartile (Q3) is 11?
MisconceptionName: Believes interquartile range is the difference between one of the quartiles and the minimum value

ConstructName: Identify questions involving the calculation of the volume of a rectangular prism
QuestionText: A warehouse has a rectangular section measuring 25m in length, 10m in width, and 8m in height. What is the volume of this section?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to calculate the volume of a prism

ConstructName: Given a cyclic quadrilateral with a diameter, identify questions involving the use of the properties of the quadrilateral to find missing angles or sides
QuestionText: In a cyclic quadrilateral ABCD with diameter AC, ∠B = 90°, ∠D = 45°. Find the measure of ∠A
MisconceptionName: Believes a cyclic quadrilateral can be self-intersecting

ConstructName: Apply exponential notation and multiplication of decimal numbers by powers of 10
QuestionText: What is the product of 4.2 × 100 ?
MisconceptionName: When multiplying a decimal by a power of 10, just adds a zero to the end of the number, not changing the place value of the digits

ConstructName: Evaluate an expression involving exponents and multiplication
MisconceptionName: Believes that when multiplying a number with a power, the multiplier is added onto the power

ConstructName: Solving simultaneous linear equations using the elimination method
QuestionText: Solve for x: 3x + 2y = 17, 2x + 4y = 11
MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they multiply both equations by the LCM of the coefficients of the term being eliminated

ConstructName: Recognize the effects of multiplying and dividing by powers of 10 on decimal numbers
QuestionText: A bookshelf is 0.8 meters tall. A second bookshelf is ten times taller. How tall is the second bookshelf?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that dividing both numbers in a multiplication sum by the same power of 10 results in equal answers

ConstructName: Characterize triangles based on the equality of their sides
QuestionText: In a triangle, if all sides are equal and all angles are 60 degrees, what type of triangle is it?
MisconceptionName: Confuses scalene and equilateral triangles

ConstructName: Calculate the volume of a right circular cylinder
QuestionText: A cylindrical water tank has a height of 10 feet and a radius of 4 feet. What is the volume of the tank in cubic feet?
MisconceptionName: Thinks a cylinder is a prism

ConstructName: Function Composition, specifically (f ∘ g)(x)
QuestionText: If f(x) = 3x + 2 and g(x) = 2x - 1, find (f ∘ g)(x).
AnswerBText: 6x - 1 + 2, with the variable x still in f(x)
MisconceptionName: Believes a composite function requires you to place the inner function next to the variable of the outer function instead of replacing it

ConstructName: Apply scalar multiplication of vectors by fractions.
QuestionText: A vector \(\overrightarrow{v}\)  is shown as \(\begin{pmatrix}6 \\ 8\end{pmatrix}\). Find \(\frac{1}{2}\overrightarrow{v}\).
MisconceptionName: When multiplying a vector by a fraction, adds the numerator to the top number of the vector, and the denominator to the bottom number of the vector.

ConstructName: Comparing a given inequality to new inequalities in terms of magnitude
QuestionText: Which new inequality is true based on the given inequality \( y < 5 \)? Determine the correct inequality for 'x', \( x < 3y \), \( x < 4y \), \( x < y \), or \( x > y \) to go along with \( y < 5 \).
MisconceptionName: Does not understand the 'less than' inequality notation

ConstructName: Sequences and Series - Finding the nth term of an arithmetic sequence
QuestionText: In an arithmetic sequence, the first term is 2 and the common difference is 3. What is the 8th term?
MisconceptionName: When asked for a specific term in a sequence, just gives the position number

ConstructName: Highest Common Factor (HCF)
QuestionText: Find the HCF of the numbers in the set: 12, 18, 24, 36
MisconceptionName: Believes the smallest number in a set of numbers is always their highest common factor

ConstructName: Comparing and applying absolute value
QuestionText: What is the absolute value of the number -8?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the meaning of absolute value

ConstructName: Cumulative Frequency Analysis
QuestionText: A survey showed that 50 students preferred Football, 70 preferred Basketball, and 30 preferred Volleyball. What is the cumulative frequency of students who preferred either Football or Basketball?
MisconceptionName: Confuses frequency of one class with cumulative frequency

ConstructName: Convert a division to a multiplication by taking the reciprocal of the divisor
QuestionText: Express the division 48 ÷ 6 as a multiplication
MisconceptionName: Thinks we can't write an equivalent multiplication sum for a division sum by using a reciprocal

ConstructName: A circle with a central angle corresponding to an arc on the circle and uses the relationship between the arc and corresponding central angle to find missing information.
QuestionText: A circle has a radius of 4 cm. If the arc corresponding to a 45° central angle has a length of 2π cm, and another arc corresponding to a 135° central angle, find the length of the 135° arc.
MisconceptionName: Thinks adjacent angles are equal

ConstructName: Interpret and construct scatter graphs to identify relationships and correlations between variables
QuestionText: A student collected data on the number of hours studied and the exam scores for a group of students. The scatter graph below shows the relationship between hours studied (x) and exam scores (y). Should a line of best fit be drawn on this graph to identify the relationship? ![A scatter graph with no correlation between hours studied and exam scores.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes a line of best fit can be drawn on a scatter graph with no relationship or correlation

ConstructName: Analysing and interpreting data presented in stem and leaf diagrams
QuestionText:
The stem and leaf diagram represents the ages of a group of students in a class. What is the mean age of the students in the class?

Stem | Leaf
4   | 2 5 7
5   | 0 1 4 8
6   | 2 9
MisconceptionName: When finding the mean of the data in a stem and leaf diagram, thinks you find the mean of the stem numbers

ConstructName: Midpoints and distance between points on the number line and coordinate plane
QuestionText: What is the lower bound for the sum of two intervals [a, b] and [-3, -2] where a is 2 less than b.
MisconceptionName: Misunderstands how to calculate the lower bound in a sum, believes it is found by adding both lower bounds

ConstructName: Find the measure of the angle in a quadrilateral given the measures of other angles
QuestionText: In quadrilateral ABCD, angle A measures 80 degrees and angle B measures 50 degrees.  The sum of the measures of the remaining two angles is?
MisconceptionName: Thinks co-interior angles sum to 360 degrees

ConstructName: Find the greatest common divisor (GCD) or highest common factor (HCF) of two numbers
QuestionText: Find the HCF of 24 and 42.
MisconceptionName: Identifies a common factor but not the highest common factor

ConstructName: Convert between units of mass
QuestionText: A store sells apples in 250-gram packets or 0.5-kilogram packets. Which statement is true about the 0.5-kilogram packet of apples?
AnswerAText: Two 0.5-kilogram packets of apples is 1000 grams
AnswerBText: Two 0.5-kilogram packets of apples is 50 grams
MisconceptionName: Does not think a kilogram is a unit of mass

ConstructName: Evaluation of an algebraic expression as a simplified fraction
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 7 shelves, and each shelf has 12 boxes of books. What fraction of a shelf is taken up by the boxes if one shelf has 0 boxes of pens and the rest have the same number of boxes of pens as boxes of books?
MisconceptionName: Believes a fraction cannot have a numerator of 0

ConstructName: Identify patterns in sequences of numbers including triangular numbers
QuestionText: Find the next number in the pattern: 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, ?
MisconceptionName: Believes all triangle numbers are odd

ConstructName: Changing mixed fractions to improper fractions
QuestionText: Change 3 2/4 to an improper fraction
MisconceptionName: Uses numerator as whole part of a fraction

ConstructName: Using factor trees to divide multi-digit numbers.
QuestionText: Jennifer is using a factor tree to divide 48 by 6. One step in her factor tree is 48 ÷ ? = 8, and the ? is actually 6. If the next number to divide by is 2, what is the next divisor she should find in the factor tree to get to her answer of 8?
MisconceptionName: When finding a missing number in a factor tree, multiplies by the factor given rather than dividing.

ConstructName: Elevations of cross-sections of 3D shapes, using a given 2D representation
QuestionText: Draw the elevation of the picture below, viewed from the left. The 3D shape consists of two rectangular prisms joined together. The bottom layer is 2 cm tall and has dimensions of 4 cm by 2 cm. The top layer is 4 cm tall and has dimensions of 4 cm by 2 cm.  What should be the dimensions of the 2D elevation of the bottom layer ? The same units must be used throughout.
MisconceptionName: Thinks that when drawing the elevation, the bottom layer does not need to be included

ConstructName: Simplify algebraic expressions by finding the greatest common factor (GCF)
QuestionText: What is the greatest common factor (GCF) of the terms in the expression \(4ab + 8b\)
MisconceptionName: Identifies a letter as a common factor but doesn't identify a number as a common factor

ConstructName: Calculate distances between points on a coordinate plane using the distance formula
QuestionText: What is the distance between points A(3, 4) and B(6, 8) on a coordinate plane?
MisconceptionName: When finding the distance between 2 points, believes the distance is the coordinate of the furthest point from origin

ConstructName: Find the area and perimeter of a sector of a circle
QuestionText: If a sector has a central angle of 30 degrees and a radius of 4 cm, what is the area of the sector in square centimeters? Use π = 22/7
MisconceptionName: Confuses angle of a sector with the radius

ConstructName: Scale up a recipe in direct proportion to increase the number of servings
QuestionText: A recipe for making 4 servings of cookies requires 3/4 cup of sugar. How many cups of sugar are required for 12 servings?
MisconceptionName: Adds rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems

ConstructName: Calculate fluid pressure in a given situation
QuestionText: A block of ice with a mass of 500 kg and a base area of 2 square meters is floating on water. What is the pressure exerted by the ice on the water?
AnswerAText: 2450 Pa, since pressure is 500*g/2 m* 9.8m/ s * is 2450 Pa.(g = 9.8 m/s, P= F/A = mg/A=500/2m * m/s =2450)
MisconceptionName: Thinks pressure is force per unit volume

ConstructName: Subtract fractions from integers
QuestionText: Solve the equation: 5 - 3/4
MisconceptionName: when subtracting a fraction from an integer, just adds their absolute value and places a negative sign in front

ConstructName: Simplify Algebraic Expressions by Factorising
QuestionText: Factorise the algebraic expression 12x^2y + 8xy^2
MisconceptionName: Does not break down all factors in a factor tree to primes

ConstructName: Manipulate basic transformations in column vector form
QuestionText: Given a translation matrix -3, 2  what is the new position of the point A after applying this transformation if it started at position vector 8, 5 ?
MisconceptionName: Thinks a negative y value in a column vector means to move up rather than down

ConstructName: Find the equation of a line in slope-intercept form given the slope and a point on the line
QuestionText: A line has a slope of 3 and passes through the point (2,4). What is the equation of the line in slope-intercept form?
MisconceptionName: Confuses a constant with a variable

ConstructName: Solve time problems involving duration between clock times in hours and minutes
QuestionText: It takes Tim 2.5 hours to paint a wall, and he starts painting at 9:20 AM. What time will it be when he finishes painting the wall?
MisconceptionName: When solving time problems, finds the difference in the hours and the difference in the minutes but then assumes the minutes will be added on to the number of hours

ConstructName: Multiply a number by a decimal to find a percentage of the number
QuestionText: If a shirt costs $80 and a 20% discount is applied, how much will you have to pay for the shirt?
MisconceptionName: Thinks you can multiply by a decimal to find a multiple of a number

ConstructName: Find the perimeter of a composite shape made of squares
QuestionText: A shape is formed from three squares with side length 4 units, 5 units, and 4 units, placed side by side with shared sides not included in the perimeter. What is the perimeter of this combined shape?
MisconceptionName: Believes knowing the perimeter of squares does not give you enough information to find the perimeter of combined shapes using those squares

ConstructName: Real-world problems involving proportional reasoning where a ratio of quantities with different units needs to be interpreted or calculated
QuestionText: A water tank can be filled at a rate of 30 litres per minute. At this rate, if the tank is filled with 90 litres of water, how many minutes will it be 'twice as high' or double that amount in the tank?
MisconceptionName: Guesses when something is 'twice as high/much', rather than multiplying by 2

ConstructName: Calculate linear gradients using coordinate geometry
QuestionText: Find the gradient of the line that passes through the points (2, 3) and (4, 5).
MisconceptionName: Believes gradient is the sum of y the coordinates divided by the sum of the x co-ordinates

ConstructName: Surface Area of a 3D shape
QuestionText: A rectangular prism has a base area of 12cm² and height of 5cm. What is the total surface area of the prism?
MisconceptionName: Believes edges of a 3D shape do not include edges of base

ConstructName: Apply the rule for multiplying with the exponent
QuestionText: A shirt is marked down by 5% four times.  If the original price is $80, what is the new price of the shirt after four markdowns, represented by (-0.05)^4 * 80
MisconceptionName: When calculating the power of a negative number, thinks they can ignore the sign when multiplying and then put a negative sign back on at the end, regardless of the power

ConstructName: Distinguish between the order of operations for expressions with parentheses and exponents
QuestionText: Simplify the expression: 3(2 + 4)²
MisconceptionName: Orders exponents before following order of operations inside parentheses

ConstructName: Factorise algebraic expressions by identifying a common factor
QuestionText: Factorise the expression \( 8x + 4y + 6 \).
MisconceptionName: When factorising, thinks the smallest coefficient will be the numerical factor, regardless of whether it divides into all terms

ConstructName: Factorising quadratic expressions in the form ax^2 + bx + c into the form (x + d)(x + e)
QuestionText: Factorise the quadratic expression 2x^2 + 7x + 3 into its equivalent double-bracketed form.
MisconceptionName: When factorising into double brackets, finds the two values which sum to give the constant rather than the coefficient of x

ConstructName: Create a frequency distribution table that provides a frequency density column.
QuestionText: A survey of exam scores indicates the following data: 1-10 (4), 11-20 (5), 21-30 (3), 31-40 (6), 41-50 (5). Determine the frequency density of scores falling between 1-10 and between 21-30.
AnswerBText: 0.4 (4 x 10), 0.6 (6 x 3, implied 3 x 10 then not using data for 21-30 range, not even 20 but also 3 x 10 implies actually 3 score no. multiplying with class width of a non applicable given 10)
MisconceptionName: Believes class width multiplied by frequency gives frequency density

ConstructName: Measuring line segments with a ruler
QuestionText: A picture frame is 15.5 inches wide. If you want to measure the width from the left edge, where should you place the 0 mark on the ruler?
AnswerAText: No 0 mark is needed, use either edge of the ruler
AnswerBText: Place the 0 on the left edge of the picture frame but read from 0. Place the 0 directly on the edge, the picture frame is then 15.5 inches wide. In that case 15 inches is left edge to right edge of the zero point  and the 0.5 left are the end bit 0.5 inches wide, so would the 0 point not be here
MisconceptionName: When measuring a line segment with a ruler, assumes the line starts at 0

ConstructName: Identify questions involving direct variation and inverse proportion
QuestionText: A bakery sells a total of 480 muffins per day. They sell muffins in packs of 6 and packs of 8. If they sell x packs of 6 muffins, how many packs of 8 muffins do they sell, if the number of packs is inversely proportional to the pack size?
AnswerAText: 8 times 80 divided by 6, or 80 times 4 divided by 3, which equals 320 divided by 3, 320/8 = 40  or 106.6667/3 - x packs of 8 muffins or 40 - 8/6 * x
MisconceptionName: Believes the two variables have to add to the same value in inverse proportion

ConstructName: Interpret and calculate gradient from the equation of a linear graph in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText: What is the gradient of the graph shown by the equation: y = -3/2x + 2 ?
MisconceptionName: Does not check the labelling of the axes

ConstructName: Apply multiplication to compare ratios and equivalent ratios to solve proportion problems
QuestionText: A music festival has an artist for every 750 patrons. If the music festival has 3750 patrons, how many artists does it have?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up total and part in ratio

ConstructName: Reasoning with inverse and direct proportion relationships
QuestionText: The volume of water (V) in a container is directly proportional to the pressure (P) of the pump. If 240 liters of water is pumped with a pressure of 16 kilograms per square meter, find the constant of proportionality (k) when the pumping pressure is doubled to 32 kilograms per square meter. Then, use k to find the amount of water (in liters) that can be pumped under the new pressure if a 4.5 factor is applied on the constant.
MisconceptionName: When working with inverse and direct proportion, forgets to apply the root or index to find k, but remembers when doing the second calculation

ConstructName: Plotting points on the Cartesian plane using coordinates
QuestionText: What are the coordinates of point A on the grid? ![A graph with point A in quadrant 1 with 3 hash marks on the x axis and 4 hash marks on the y axis to the left and below point A.]()
MisconceptionName: Not considered the y value when reading coordinates

ConstructName: Percentage calculations and discounts
QuestionText: A store offers a 30% discount on everything. How much will you pay for a $100 item with the discount?
MisconceptionName: Believes 30% is equivalent to 1/3

ConstructName: Compare numbers involving decimals in the hundredths place
QuestionText: Which number is larger, 4.52 or 4.5?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand that having values after the decimal point makes a number larger than a number with the same units but no decimal places

ConstructName: Identify the area of triangular bases in a 3D shape
QuestionText: In an isosceles triangle, where 2 sides are equal, with a base length of 12cm and height of 5cm, what is the area of the triangular base? The isosceles triangle can be split into 2 right angled triangles.
MisconceptionName: Uses the whole base rather than half the base when forming a right angled triangle from an isosceles triangle

ConstructName: Reading and writing 24-hour time
QuestionText: What is 3:00 PM in 24-hour format?
MisconceptionName: Writes times in the afternoon as if 10 is midday on a 24 hour clock

ConstructName: Identify and calculate lengths of arcs and chords in circles
QuestionText: A chord is 12cm in a circle with radius 8cm. Find the length of the arc subtended by the chord at the circumference of the circle.
AnswerAText: Can be calculated using correct procedure
AnswerBText: 0cm, or the chord is the arc
MisconceptionName: Thinks a chord does not have to start and end at the circumference of the circle

ConstructName: Interpret and analyze data presented in histograms
QuestionText: A histogram shows exam scores for 100 students. The histogram has 5 classes, with the first class representing scores from 0-20 and having a frequency of 10. Which class has the greatest density, assuming class widths are always 20 marks in this histogram?
AnswerAText: Class with the greatest frequency divided by 20, since each class has the same range
AnswerBText: Class width of 20 represents the greatest density as it is the greatest frequency
MisconceptionName: Believes class width represents frequency in a histogram

ConstructName: Find the exterior angle of a triangle using the number of sides of a polygon
QuestionText: In a regular octagon, what is the measure of an exterior angle of the polygon?
MisconceptionName: Finds the sum of the missing angles but not the angle being asked

ConstructName: Reading and writing multi-digit numbers
QuestionText: A book has 421 pages. Write the number of pages in words.
MisconceptionName: Believes digits of a number are read/written from right to left

ConstructName: Sampling methods for survey research that include both random and stratified methods.
QuestionText: A market researcher wants to know the average income of the metropolitan area, with breakdowns by neighborhood. Which sampling method should be used?
MisconceptionName: Confuses random and stratified sampling methods

ConstructName: Interpret bar charts or histograms showing frequency distributions
QuestionText: A bar chart shows the favorite sports of students at a school with the following data: Football (24 students), Basketball (18 students), Volleyball (12 students) and Total students (54). What is the relative frequency of students who prefer Volleyball?
MisconceptionName: Gives frequency when asked for relative frequency

ConstructName: Prime Factorization of composite numbers
QuestionText: Find the prime factorization of 12, if it can be written as a product of 2 and some other prime number, list both factors as many times as they occur. Is 2 * 2 * 3 correct ?
AnswerBText: No, the correct answer is 2 * 3, since we do not add the factors when there is another instance of 2
MisconceptionName: Believes that repeated prime factors are only counted once

ConstructName: Calculating the range of a dataset
QuestionText: Find the range of the dataset: 4, 8, 15, 15, 23.
AnswerBText: Cannot calculate the range with repeated values
MisconceptionName: Thinks that we cannot calculate the range if values are repeated

ConstructName: Identify and apply properties of co-interior angles in parallel lines.
QuestionText: Two lines, AB and CD, are parallel and intersected by a transversal. ∠ABE and ∠CDE are co-interior angles. If ∠ABE measures 40 degrees, what is the measure of ∠CDE?
MisconceptionName: Does not know that co-interior angles must be in parallel lines

ConstructName: Identify the properties of a kite
QuestionText: A kite has diagonals that intersect at a right angle. If one pair of the opposite sides of this shape are 7cm and the other pair are 9cm, what would this shape be classified as?
MisconceptionName: Thinks a kite has one pair of parallel sides

ConstructName: Navigation using grid references and bearings (measured in degrees clockwise from north)
QuestionText: A ship is currently at grid reference (4, 6) on a map. If the ship sails 10km on a bearing of 270° and then 15km on a bearing of 0°, what are its new coordinates?
AnswerAText: (4, 6 + 10 + 0) = (4, 16) then (4 + 0, 16 + 15) = (4, 31)  The correct solution involves simple addition of the coordinates but only during the second leg of the trip in the Y axis since the ship sails north; however, in this navigation problem,  ships first sails east-west on a 270 degree bearing and thus the 10 km is subtracted in the Y coordinates (which is not the initial direction of the ship) and then must be recalculated properly.
MisconceptionName: Forgets to add starting value when calculating new coordinates

ConstructName: Divide fractions
QuestionText: A pizza was cut into 1/8 pieces. If 1/4 of the pizza was eaten, how many whole pizzas were eaten?
MisconceptionName: When dividing fractions, divides by the reciprocal, instead of multiplies

ConstructName: Simplifying fractions by dividing the numerator and the denominator by their greatest common divisor
QuestionText: Simplify the fraction: 8/16
MisconceptionName: Thinks the reciprocal of n, 1/n = 0.n

ConstructName: Angles in a circle
QuestionText: In the circle below,
MisconceptionName: Believes that an exterior angle can have a value of 360 degrees

ConstructName: Covert between units of time, such as minutes to seconds
QuestionText: Tom can jog around a block in 5 minutes. How many seconds does it take for Tom to jog around the block?
MisconceptionName: Thinks there are 100 seconds in a minute

ConstructName: Identifying modes in a set of data
QuestionText: What is the mode of the following set of exam scores: 75, 82, 75, 91, 75, 67, 82, 75?
MisconceptionName: Believes you find the mode by calculating the mean

ConstructName: Real-world problems involving percentages and multi-step calculations to resolve
QuestionText: A shirt is on sale at 15% discount. If a $50 shirt is bought during this sale, and there's an 8% sales tax, how much will the person pay after discount and sales tax?
MisconceptionName: Divides instead of multiplies when multiplying by a decimal

ConstructName: Convert between units of mass within the metric system
QuestionText: How many kilograms are in 3 tonnes?
MisconceptionName: Thinks there are 10,000kg in a tonne

ConstructName: Estimate sums and differences by rounding numbers to the nearest ten or hundred
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 247 books on it. Estimate the total number of books on three identical bookshelves. Explain your reasoning
MisconceptionName: Confuses place value when rounding to estimate

ConstructName: Rationalise the denominator of a fraction involving a surd
QuestionText: Rationalise the denominator of the fraction: \(\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}\)
MisconceptionName: When rationalising the denominator, confuses the numerator with the denominator

ConstructName: Interpret histograms, including identifying patterns, trends, and comparing the area of bars.
QuestionText: A histogram with a class interval of 10-19 has a frequency of 5, while a class interval of 20-29 has a frequency of 10. If a uniform frequency density is applied across the class width, what is the ratio of the areas of the two bars in the histogram?
MisconceptionName: Believes class width multiplied by frequency gives the area of the bar in a histogram

ConstructName: Linear Equations of the form y = mx
QuestionText: Solve for y in the equation 2y + 3x = 6 when x = 0
AnswerAText: y=-3x+3 and then y=3 for x=0
MisconceptionName: Does not equate y=-x with x=-y

ConstructName: Measure and record the size of angles using degrees
QuestionText: A protractor is used to measure the size of an angle, the result of the measure is recorded. What is the correct unit and measurement for recording the size of an angle in the diagram if the angle measures up to 58 marks on the protractor.![An angle being measured using a protractor, scale in degrees.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the size of an angle can be given as a word rather than a number

ConstructName: Understanding and applying Rotation in Coordinate Geometry to find the new coordinates of a point after rotation about the Origin or other point
QuestionText: A point P is at (-3, 4) which undergoes a 90° clockwise rotation about the origin. What is the new position of the point P?
MisconceptionName: When identifying the center of rotation, chooses a point with the wrong y-value

ConstructName: Scaling factors for enlargement
QuestionText: A bookcase with a height of 120cm is to be enlarged so that it now has a height of 240cm. What is the scale factor of the enlargement?
MisconceptionName: Assumes that an enlargement is always from the smaller object to the bigger one

ConstructName: Identify equivalent fractions with cancellation involving division of fractions
QuestionText: A fraction simplification problem has a numerator of 18 and a denominator of 30, if we divide the numerator by 6 and the denominator by 6 to simplify this fraction. What would be the result?
AnswerBText: 18/30 = 3/5 does not apply, 18/6 / 30/6 = 3/5 simplifying incorrectly 3/5 then becomes 3 * 6 / 5 * 6 = 18/30 so then 18/6 = 3 and 30/6 = 5 so 18/6 / 30/6 is 18/20 simplifying down further 18/20 is 9/10
MisconceptionName: Believes that n/n = n, instead of 1</Misconception

ConstructName: Understand set theory, specifically identifying the complement of an intersection of two sets
QuestionText:
In the diagram below, set A represents students who play soccer and set B represents students who play basketball. What set represents students who play neither soccer nor basketball? 
![A Venn Diagram showing two overlapping sets A and B]
AnswerAText: The complement of A ∩ B (A intersection B) or the complement of A ∪ B (A union B)
AnswerBText: The complement of neither A nor B, the complement of A or the complement of B
MisconceptionName: Believes the intersection of two complements can be found using the complement of the intersection

ConstructName: Converts fractional measures to decimal measures when solving problems involving distance, weight, or time
QuestionText: The distance from point A to point B is 3/4 mile. How far is it in decimal form?
MisconceptionName: When converting a fraction to a decimal, divides the denominator by the numerator

ConstructName: Compass Bearings and Their Relationship to North
QuestionText: A hiker faces a landmark that is 070°.  What is the angle to the north that the hiker must turn to face north.?
MisconceptionName: When finding bearings, finds the back bearing to what the question is actually asking

ConstructName: Interpret and construct grouped frequency tables and use these to estimate the mean, median, mode, and range for a set of data
QuestionText:
The table below shows the test scores of a group of students. What is the total frequency of the groups with scores 50-59 and 60-69?

 Score   | Frequency
---------|---------
 40-49  | 5
 50-59  | 8
 60-69  | 12
 70-79  | 10
 80-89  | 7
 90-99  | 3
MisconceptionName: Assumes the third column of a grouped frequency table is always cumulative frequency

ConstructName: Graphs of the form y = mx, where m is the gradient
QuestionText: What are the coordinates of the point where the line y = -2x intersects the y-axis?
MisconceptionName: When a point is on an axis, gives both coordinates as the value it's at on the axis

ConstructName: Apply index laws with fractional, integer, and negative exponents to expressions with rational bases
QuestionText: Simplify the expression: 6 * √6
MisconceptionName: When multiplying a surd by an integer, believes the value under the surd can be swapped with the integer

ConstructName: Trigonometric methods for finding bearings Involving 3-digit bearings
QuestionText: A plane is flying north east, and has a bearing of 035 from location A to a destination B. From B, a ship is heading SE, what bearing would it have from B if it travelled in exactly the opposite direction to the ship?
MisconceptionName: When finding bearings, finds the bearing going in the reverse direction to the one stated

ConstructName: Calculating the angles in a quadrilateral when one angle is given and three internal angles are known
QuestionText: A quadrilateral ABCD has the following angles: ∠A = x°, ∠B = 80°, ∠C = 60°, and ∠D = 50°. What is the value of x?
MisconceptionName: Finds interior angle rather than given angle

ConstructName: Sketch the equation of a straight line in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText: Sketch the equation y = 2x - 3 on a coordinate grid.
AnswerAText: A line passing through (0, -3) and (1, -1) with a positive gradient
AnswerBText: A line passing through (0, 3) and (1, -1) with a positive gradient
MisconceptionName: Believes the equation of a straight line is y=-mx-c

ConstructName: Identify the relationship between angles formed by a transversal that intersects two parallel lines.
QuestionText: What can be said about the relationship between angle a and angle b in the given diagram? ![A transversal crossing two parallel lines, with a labelled angle 'a' on one line and 'b' on the other line but not on the same side of the transversal and not next to each other but vertically opposite each other]
AnswerBText: They are alternate interior angles, therefore corresponding, so they are supplementary.
MisconceptionName: Believes only angles on parallel lines can be called "corresponding"

ConstructName: Solve proportion problems involving scales of 2D shapes
QuestionText: A blueprint of a floor plan is drawn to a scale of 1 cm to 2.5 m. If the length of the living room on the blueprint is 4.8 cm, find the actual length of the living room.
MisconceptionName: Finds a scale factor but forgets to multiply the original value in proportion questions

ConstructName: Analyze experimental results and compare them to theoretical probabilities
QuestionText: A coin is flipped 100 times and it lands on heads 65 times. What is the experimental probability of the coin landing on heads?
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise that probabilities of all possible outcomes will sum to 1

ConstructName: Arithmetic sequences and their nth terms
QuestionText: Fred's savings form an arithmetic sequence where he saves $100 on the first week and increases the amount by $20 each subsequent week. What will be the amount saved in the 8th week?
MisconceptionName: Thinks n=0 for the first term in a sequence

ConstructName: Interpret a histogram with equal or unequal class intervals to find the cumulative frequency
QuestionText: A histogram shows the number of hours of exercise per week for a group of people, the data is divided into equal class intervals of 2 hours. To find the number of people who exercise for 4 hours or less per week, what do you do to the heights of the first two columns of the histogram? ![A histogram with class intervals 0-2 hours (10 people), 2-4 hours (12 people), 4-6 hours (7 people), 6-8 hours (5 people), 8-10 hours (8 people)]()
AnswerAText: Add the heights of the first two columns (10 + 12 = 22 people)
AnswerBText: Calculate the total area of the first two columns ((10 x 2) + (12 x 2) = 44 people)
MisconceptionName: Confuses cumulative frequency and frequency density

ConstructName: Interpreting Venn Diagrams with three sets (A, B, and C)
QuestionText: A survey of students in a school had the following results: 25 students liked only chess, 18 students liked only basketball, 32 students liked both chess and basketball, 20 students liked only volleyball, 15 students liked chess and volleyball, 10 students liked basketball and volleyball. What is the total number of students that liked at least one of the three sports?
MisconceptionName: Confuses the value outside of a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram

ConstructName: Find missing lengths of right-angled triangles using trigonometric ratios
QuestionText: A right-angled triangle has an angle of 60 degrees, its hypotenuse has a length of 10cm, and the side adjacent to this angle is p. Which ratio would you use to find the value of p?
MisconceptionName: Confuses adjacent and opposite sides

ConstructName: Evaluate the quality of a data set
QuestionText: A pupil records the colours of cars passing a junction in four categories: Red, Blue, Green, Black. How many cars must she observe to make her data more reliable, assuming only one colour is added, colour 'Grey', still qualitative, she keeps in the same category as, black thus having 4 categories of car colours recorded. With six recorded at least how many others can she classify under - 'other than those three colours'
AnswerAText: Enough to give a smaller margin of error
AnswerBText: At least 10 of each colour category
MisconceptionName: Believes qualitative data can be continuous

ConstructName: Calculate the percentage change in a value
QuestionText: A store originally sold a shirt for $80. After a sale, the price of the shirt was reduced to $64. What is the percentage change in price of the shirt?
MisconceptionName: Believes you can divide the change by 100 to find the percentage change

ConstructName: Calculate the volume of rectangular prisms
QuestionText: A rectangular prism has a base area of 12m² and a height of 8m. What is the volume of the prism in cubic meters?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to calculate volume

ConstructName: Circle problems involving circumference and area
QuestionText: A circular park has a walking path around it. The path is 3.5 meters wide throughout. If the path covers a total area of 5540 m² and the original radius of the park was R meters, what was R?
MisconceptionName: confuses circumference and area

ConstructName: Apply the concept of function composition and application to solve problems
QuestionText: If f(x) = x + 2 and g(x) = 2x - 1, find (f ∘ g)(2).
MisconceptionName: Thinks that they can combine functions in a function machine before applying them to the input

ConstructName: Properties of quadrilaterals
QuestionText: A square ABCD is drawn. If the diagonals AC and BD bisect each other at point E, and the side length of the square is 6cm, what is the measure of angle AED?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the diagonals of a square bisect at right angles

ConstructName: Interpret and analyze misleading or biased statistical representations, including diagrams
QuestionText: A recent survey showed that 50% of people in City A and 60% of people in City B said they supported an environmental initiative. The results are represented in the bar graph below: ![A graph where the bars for City A and City B are about the same height but the bars for City B are much wider]
AnswerAText: The graph may be misleading as the wider bars for City B may cause the perception that the difference in support is larger than 10%.
AnswerBText: The graph is a fair representation as the difference in heights is still 10%.
MisconceptionName: Underestimates the impact of the size of images in a misleading statistical diagram

ConstructName: Calculating part-whole relationships in real-world contexts using decimals and fractions to represent wholes
QuestionText: Emily has 4/8 of a box of chocolates to pack in a store display, and her coworker has the rest. If Emily gives her coworker 1 more piece for display, and there are 24 chocolates in the box, how many chocolates does Emily's coworker have now?
AnswerAText: 12 + 1 = 13, then 12 of total isn't hers so 12 of 24 total the coworkers original is 12 and adding 1 it now becomes 13, it is more accurate to not have any fraction.
AnswerBText: 12 + 1 of 8 equals 13/8 13 and 3 eighths of a chocolate is what Emily coworker now has
MisconceptionName: Believes the total of a part whole model is always 1 (or equivalent) instead of the given total

ConstructName: Apply ASA (Angle-Side-Angle) and SSS (Side-Side-Side) postulates to prove triangles are congruent
QuestionText: Determine if triangle ABC and triangle DEF are congruent. Triangle ABC has angels measuring 60 degrees, 70 degrees, and 50 degrees. Corresponding angles in triangle DEF measure 60 degrees, 70 degrees, and 50 degrees. Side AB measures 6.7cm, and corresponding side DE measures 6.7cm. Side BC measures 7.1cm, and corresponding side EF measures 6.8cm.
AnswerAText: No, triangles ABC and DEF are not congruent.
AnswerBText: Yes, triangles ABC and DEF are congruent.
MisconceptionName: Thinks Angle-Angle-Angle triangles are congruent

ConstructName: Apply the concept of multiplying fractions to find the product of two fractions
QuestionText: What is the product of 2/3 and 3/5?
MisconceptionName: Believes when multiplying fractions you cross multiply top left and bottom right for numerator, and the other diagonal for denominator

ConstructName: Apply the Order of Operations to simplify expressions involving exponents and multiple operations
QuestionText: Simplify: -6 ÷ (-2)^2
MisconceptionName: Thinks a divide and a negative sign next to each other makes a plus

ConstructName: Identify the measure of an unknown angle in a given diagram
QuestionText: What is the measure of angle \(x\)? ![A triangle with an angle labelled 60 degrees, another angle labelled 90 degrees and the third angle, \(x\), is also 90 degrees looking ]()
MisconceptionName: Believes that angles that look like they are a right-angle are always 90 degrees

ConstructName: Simplify surds involving numbers
QuestionText: Simplify \( \sqrt{50} \)
AnswerBText: \( 7\sqrt{2} \) - when the square of seven was divided out of the square root of forty nine, the square root of one is just one leaving the square root of two
MisconceptionName: When simplifying surds, does not understand that the simplified root is what is left after dividing out the largest square number

ConstructName: Operations with cube roots
QuestionText: If ∛(x) = 5, what is the value of x?
MisconceptionName: Mistakes cube root for cubing the number

ConstructName: Dividing multi-digit numbers by single-digit factors
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 18 books, and you want to put them into boxes that hold 3 books each. How many boxes can you fill?
MisconceptionName: Believes 1 is not a factor of a number

ConstructName: Function composition, where one function is the input of another function
QuestionText: Given the function composition \( f(g(x)) \), where \( f(x) = x^2 + 3 \) and \( g(x) = 2x - 1 \), find \( f(g(4)) \)
MisconceptionName: Believes a composite function multiplies the functions together

ConstructName: Identify questions that can be solved using the formula speed = distance / time
QuestionText: A car travels from city A to city B, covering a distance of 240 miles in 4 hours. What is the speed of the car?
MisconceptionName: Believes speed = time / distance

ConstructName: Draw isosceles triangles
QuestionText: A student is asked to draw an isosceles triangle with one angle measuring 60 degrees and the two equal sides of length 6cm each. What should be the length of the third side if the two equal sides are the left and right sides of the triangle?
AnswerAText: Depends on the unlabeled angle,  but either equal to the other sides or less than the other sides in some scenarios
MisconceptionName: Believes that when constructing triangles, all sides should be measured from the same point

ConstructName: Interpret and analyze data presented in two-way tables
QuestionText:
A survey of students' favorite sports in two different schools, Springfield and Oakdale, is provided in the table below. How many more students prefer basketball in Springfield than in Oakdale?

|  | Springfield | Oakdale |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Basketball | 45 | 30 |
| Football | 25 | 35 |
| Soccer | 20 | 15 |
AnswerBText: 45 - 35 = 10 and 35 is from the football category in the bad answer from other category, no answer in the football line, and he incorrectly chose another football category number in bad answer
MisconceptionName: When comparing data, only compares one category of data rather than comparing the totals

ConstructName: Expressing fractions with decimal denominators as fractions with whole number denominators (e.g. 1.5 = 3/2)
QuestionText: Write the decimal 0.25 as a fraction with a whole number denominator.
MisconceptionName: Used the digits of the decimal as the denominator

ConstructName: Average speed for a journey is calculated by dividing total distance traveled by total time taken
QuestionText: A car traveled from City A to City B at an average speed of 60 km/h and took 3 hours. On the return trip, the car traveled at an average speed of 40 km/h and took 4 hours. What is the average speed for the entire round trip?
MisconceptionName: Finds the average speed by averaging the two speeds, rather than averaging the total distance divided by the total time

ConstructName: Rationalise the denominator in a fraction by multiplying with a suitable form of 1
QuestionText: Rationalise the denominator of \( 2 / \sqrt{5} \).
AnswerBText: \( 4 / 5 \) after multiplying by \( \sqrt{5} \) on numerator and denominator
MisconceptionName: Believes multiplying a number by its square root gives the square root

ConstructName: Compare fractions with different denominators
QuestionText: What is the lowest common multiple of 12 and 15?
MisconceptionName: Believes finding the product of two numbers gives their lowest common multiple

ConstructName: Expressing area of compound shapes by applying the formula for area of rectangles, triangles, and combinations of shapes
QuestionText: A rectangular garden has an area of 15m^2 and a width of 3m. If an extension to the garden, in the shape of a right-angled triangle, is to be added on, with a base of 4m, what would be the new area if the height of the triangle is twice the base length of the triangle and 4m longer than the length of the rectangular garden?
MisconceptionName: Believes that multiplying variables is the same as adding them together

ConstructName: Finding the Highest Common Factor (HCF) in worded questions
QuestionText: Tara has 12 pencils, and Ella has 18 pencils. What is the highest number of pencils that they could both pool their resources to buy an equal amount without having any left over?
MisconceptionName: Believes they need to multiply the numbers together in a worded HCF question

ConstructName: Find the length of a side in a right-angled triangle given the hypotenuse and angle, using the sine, cosine or tangent ratios
QuestionText: In triangle ABC, angle BAC is 30°. AB is 12 cm and AC is the side opposite the right angle. What is the length of AC (the hypotenuse) if AB is adjacent to the 30° angle and is 12cm while side BC is 6cm, what is side AB's opposite length  ' the side opposite the angle), to find side AC to find how far away 6cm was AC by 30° when point B is 6cm on the side adjacent side to point A to side BC.
AnswerAText: Since we are given a 30° angle and adjacent side 12cm, it will be useful to find the side opposite 6cm first use tan -  tan(30°) =  6cm / AB length  = o, so o = tan 30 o  * ab   ab 10.955512  when you put 6 on 'o' , then using the Pythagorean to now solve the triangle triangle formula (AB)² + (BC) ² =  (AC)², to solve a/c equates    (√194) cm
AnswerBText: Using (sin) only  AC hypotenuse =  opposite side / sin(30°) , since sin 30° = 0.5 hence hypotenuse 12cm  (not BC since it would be false due ab) only 6cm
MisconceptionName: Believes 0.5absin(c) requires only three sides (potentially confused with cosine rule)

ConstructName: Divide multi-digit numbers by single-digit numbers using the standard division algorithm
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 432 books to be packed into boxes that hold 9 books each. How many boxes can be filled?
MisconceptionName: Thinks the inverse of multiplication is addition

ConstructName: Calculate the perimeter of polygons
QuestionText: A triangle has sides of length 5cm, 7cm and 6cm. What is its perimeter?
MisconceptionName: Assumes triangles are isosceles if they look like they are isosceles

ConstructName: Apply percentage decrease to a number
QuestionText: A bakery is offering a 15% discount on all products for the holiday season. If a cake originally costs £25, how much will you pay for it after the discount?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that to decrease by a percentage you multiply by 1+ the decimal equivalent to that percentage

ConstructName: Calculating scale factors to enlarge 2D shapes
QuestionText: A 2D shape has been enlarged by a scale factor of 3. If the original shape had a perimeter of 8cm, what is the length of the original side that corresponds to a side of length 9cm on the enlarged shape;
MisconceptionName: Does not count from the centre of enlargement to find the image

ConstructName: Graphing and analyzing linear equations
QuestionText: A company sells products with a profit of -$5 per unit for each of the first 200 units, and $8 profit per unit for each unit sold after 200. What is the gradient (m) of the profit line after 200 units?
MisconceptionName: Believes you cannot have a negative gradient when plotting a linear sequence

ConstructName: Interpret Cumulative Frequency Tables
QuestionText: Given the data for number of people visiting a museum for the first 4 days, construct the cumulative frequency: Monday - 10 people, Tuesday - 8 people, Wednesday - 15 people, Thursday - 6 people. What is the cumulative frequency on Thursday?
MisconceptionName: Believes cumulative frequency is the product rather than sum of frequencies

ConstructName: Circle measurements, specifically the circumference of a full circle or a sector.
QuestionText: A sector of a circle has a central angle of 120 degrees and a radius of 4 inches. What is the length of the arc of this sector?
MisconceptionName: Confuses the formulas for the circumference of a full circle and the perimeter of a sector

ConstructName: Identifying interior angles of polygons
QuestionText: A regular pentagon has 5 equal interior angles, what is the size of each angle?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand what an interior angle is

ConstructName: Finding a missing length of a cuboid when given its volume and one of the dimensions
QuestionText: A rectangular cuboid has a length of 8 cm, width of 5 cm and an unknown height. If the volume of the cuboid is 400 cubic cm, what is its height?
MisconceptionName: Believes a missing length on a cuboid can be found by doing volume divided by a different length

ConstructName: Translate word problems into algebraic expressions
QuestionText: Tom has 15 boxes of pens to sell, and each box contains 8 packets of pens. If he already sold 'x' boxes, how many packets of pens does he have left to sell?
MisconceptionName: Ignores coefficients when forming an expression from a question

ConstructName: Divide fractions by multiplying by the reciprocal of the divisor
QuestionText: A chemist needs to add a 1/4 teaspoon of a spice to a recipe, but only has 3/4 teaspoon measuring spoons. What fraction of the measuring spoon should they use?
MisconceptionName: Does not perform calculations in the numerator of a fraction before division by the denominator

ConstructName: Find missing numbers in a factor tree to simplify multiplication
QuestionText:
Complete the factor tree:
7 × ? × 3 = 21 
/        \
7          3
MisconceptionName: When asked to find a missing number in a factor tree, finds any factor of the given number rather than the pair of the factor already given.

ConstructName: Construct three-dimensional (3D) drawings from given two-dimensional (2D) views such as plan and front elevation
QuestionText: A building is represented with the following plan and front elevation views.  What does the side elevation view look like?![Plan and front elevation views of a rectangular prism]( ) side elevation view?
AnswerAText: A rectangle with a base of 5m and a height of 8m
AnswerBText: A pentagon with the same dimensions as the plan view
MisconceptionName: Thinks that when drawing a plan view, you only include the top layer of the shape

ConstructName: Comparing fractions with different denominators
QuestionText: Arrange the fractions 2/3 and 3/4 in order from smallest to largest. Which fraction is smaller?
MisconceptionName: After multiplying to get a common denominator, simplifies back to the original fractions

ConstructName: Understand the properties and application of fractional exponents
QuestionText: Simplify the expression: 8^(1/3)
MisconceptionName: Believes that a fractional index means you need to find the reciprocal

ConstructName: Calculate the average speed of an object
QuestionText: A hiker travels 24 kilometers in 6 hours. What is the average speed of the hiker in kilometers per hour?
MisconceptionName: Thinks the units for speed should not contain a measure of time

ConstructName: Basic geometric properties of 3D shapes, especially polyhedra
QuestionText: How many edges do you see in the given image of a cube from one particular angle?![The cube's image, as seen from one particular angle.](http://)
MisconceptionName: Only counts visible edges

ConstructName: Calculate the volume of a rectangular prism.
QuestionText: A rectangular prism has a length of 8cm, a width of 5cm. If the height of this prism is 3cm. What is the volume ?
AnswerBText:
15 cm^3</Incomplete Answer Correct answer for Area>
<Misconception>Thinks depth is marked on the cross section of a prism</Misconception>
MisconceptionName: Thinks depth is marked on the cross section of a prism

ConstructName: Find the frequency density of uniform classes in grouped data
QuestionText: A set of exam scores are grouped into classes of width 5. A particular class has an upper bound of 45 and contains 8 scores. What is the frequency density of this class.
MisconceptionName: Confuses class width and upper bound of the class

ConstructName: Decomposing a multi-digit whole number into its place value
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 345 books, and you want to know how many hundreds, tens, and ones make up this total number. Complete the place value breakdown:  hundreds  tens  ones
MisconceptionName: Misinterprets the order of division in worded problems</Misconception

ConstructName: Interpret data presented in a histogram
QuestionText:
The histogram shows the number of books read by students in a class. If the total number of books read is 360, estimate the number of students who read between 3 and 5 books. 
![](Histogram showing frequency numbers books read: 0-2 is 60, 3-5 is x, and 5-10 is 90,  more than 10 has a frequency of 210)
MisconceptionName: When drawing a histogram, believes you plot cumulative frequency on the vertical axis

ConstructName: Solve quadratic equations by finding intersections with the x-axis
QuestionText:
What are the solutions to the equation x^2 - 4x + 4 = 0 by finding its intersections with the x-axis?
A - (2,0) and B (4,0) are the x-intercepts
MisconceptionName: Believes the solutions to an equation have opposite signs from its x intercepts

ConstructName: Shading fractions of a shape
QuestionText: A circle is divided into 8 parts. 3 of these parts are shaded. What fraction of the circle is shaded? ![A circle is divided into 8 equal parts, with 3 parts shaded.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes a smaller number of shaded parts represents a smaller fraction

ConstructName: Convert between units of length, particularly kilometers and millimeters
QuestionText: How many millimeters are in 5.2 kilometers?
MisconceptionName: Thinks there are 100mm in a km

ConstructName: Apply the input-output rule for a function machine that adds 2 to an input number to find an output value
QuestionText: A function machine is defined by the rule 'Add 2'. What will the output be when the input is 5?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that when you put an input into a function machine you apply the inverse operation rather than the operation given.

ConstructName: Compare equivalent fractions by converting between them using multiplication
QuestionText: Shade \( \frac{3}{4} \) of the rectangle, and express the shaded region as an equivalent fraction with a denominator of 8 instead of 4. What is the new numerator value in this equivalent fraction
MisconceptionName: Thinks you cannot multiply by a decimal to get equivalent fractions

ConstructName: Represent simple algebraic relationships using counters or blocks
QuestionText: Arjun has 5 boxes of pencils, and each box contains 'x' pencils. If Arjun receives 3 more boxes, and each new box also contains 'x' pencils. How many pencils does Arjun have in total now?
MisconceptionName: Does not understand use of the counters to represent algebra

ConstructName: Interpreting and analyzing linear relationships represented on a line graph
QuestionText: A coffee shop tracks the total daily sales (in dollars) and the number of customers they serve each day. What information would typically be graphed on the x-axis and which on the y-axis of a line graph showing this relationship? ![Legend with sample data with date, customers, and sales]
MisconceptionName: Confuses the dependent and independent variables on the axes of a line graph

ConstructName: Identify numbers that satisfy a specific numerical property
QuestionText: What is the smallest number greater than 1 that has exactly 3 distinct factors?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up square numbers and prime numbers

ConstructName: Identify and apply scale factor to enlarge or reduce a 2D shape
QuestionText: Catina is enlarging the given shape with a scale factor of 3/2. What are the new coordinates of point A (4,3) after enlargement?  A) (6,4.5), B) (-6,-4.5), C) (12,9), D) (2,1.5)
MisconceptionName: Thinks a fractional scale factor changes direction as well as size

ConstructName: Apply algebraic manipulations to simplify expressions involving exponents
QuestionText: Simplify \(2^{2}\)x if \(x\) is multiplied by \(x\) and then by \(2\) repeatedly
MisconceptionName: Thinks multiplying by a variable is the same as raising to the power of that variable

ConstructName: Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Sine (sin) ratio
QuestionText: Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( h \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 50 degrees, the side opposite to this is h and the hypotenuse is 10cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Believes the adjacent side is where the opposite side is in a right-angled triangle

ConstructName: Finding greatest/maximum values
QuestionText: The average daily temperatures for a city over a 5-day period were -2°C, 3°C, -5°C, -10°C, and 0°C. Which day had the greatest increase in temperature from the previous day?
MisconceptionName: Chosen the longest value rather than the greatest

ConstructName: Calculate percentage decreases in a given quantity
QuestionText: A shirt originally costs $80. After a 25% discount, how much will you pay for the shirt?
MisconceptionName: Thinks that to decrease by a percentage you just multiply by the decimal equivalent to that percentage

ConstructName: Subtracting surds from integers in math problems
QuestionText: What is the value of \( 4 - \sqrt{16} \)? Show all work
AnswerBText: 0.25  since 4/ \( \sqrt{16} \) is 4 divided by 4 or 0.25 first
MisconceptionName: When subtracting a surd from an integer, just divides the integer by the number under the surd

ConstructName: Graphing the sine function and understanding its relationship to other trigonometric functions
QuestionText: What is the amplitude of the graph with the function \( y = 2 \sin(x) \) ?
AnswerBText: Not applicable as it is undefined due to the non-linear relationship with the tan function
MisconceptionName: Believes the sin graph relates to the tan function

ConstructName: Find the area of a sector of a circle
QuestionText: A sector of a circle has a central angle of 50 degrees, and the radius of the circle is 10cm. What is the area of the sector?
AnswerBText: 50/360 x 10 x pi = 0.1389 x 10 x pi = 4.37 cm^2 (approximately)
MisconceptionName: Thinks the area of a sector is theta/360 x r x pi (forgetting the radius is squared)

ConstructName: Expressing a number as a list of prime factors using a factor tree
QuestionText:
A factor tree for the number 60 is shown below. Write the list of prime factors for 60. 
![Factor tree for 60: 60 -> 6 * 10, 6 -> 2 * 3, 10 -> 2 * 5]
MisconceptionName: Does not recognise how to write a list of prime factors from a factor tree

ConstructName: Calculate the area of an enlarged shape
QuestionText: A rectangle with an area of 16 square cm is enlarged by a scale factor of 3. What is the new area of the rectangle?
MisconceptionName: Believes that when a shape is enlarged, the area rather than the scale factor is squared

ConstructName: Converting fractions to decimals
QuestionText: Write the decimal equivalent of 3/10
MisconceptionName: Thinks 0.3 = 1/3

ConstructName: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the length of a side in a right-angled triangle
QuestionText: In a right-angled triangle, the length of the hypotenuse is 17cm and one of the legs is 8cm. What is the length of the other leg?
MisconceptionName: Adds rather than subtracts when using Pythagoras to find a shorter side

ConstructName: Questions that involve finding the gradient of a straight line between two points
QuestionText: Find the gradient of the line passing through the points (3, 4) and (6, 8).
MisconceptionName: Thinks the gradient of a line is found from 2 points by finding the length of that line between those points

ConstructName: Comparing shapes to decide if they are similar
QuestionText: Are these two triangles similar? If yes, why? ![Two triangles side lengths one triangle with side lengths 2 and 4 units and another with 4 and 8 units]
AnswerAText: Yes, they are similar, as the ratio of the sides in both triangles is the same (2:4 for the first triangle, 4:8 for the second).
AnswerBText: No, they are not similar because one is bigger than the other.
MisconceptionName: Does not realise similar has a specific mathematical meaning

ConstructName: Interpret and apply measures of spread including range, interquartile range and standard deviation
QuestionText: A dataset has values of 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 15, 18, 19, 20. Determine the value of the range of the dataset. If the lower quartile is 14 and the upper quartile is 17, what is the total range and interquartile range for the dataset with the addition of 6.
AnswerAText: The range is 8 and as 6 is below all the quartiles, new range is 14, IQR still is 3.
AnswerBText: The range is 8 and as 6 is below all the quartiles, new range is 3 and the IQR remains the same as 14.
MisconceptionName: Confuses range and interquartile range

ConstructName: Comparing and ordering fractions
QuestionText: Compare the fractions, 3/8 and 4/8. Which one is greater?
MisconceptionName: Does not know the term numerator

ConstructName: Linear equations in the form of y = mx + b
QuestionText: A bakery sold a certain number of cookies. If the cost of producing the cookies is $55 per week (regardless of how many are sold), and they sell the cookies for $2 each, what is the equation to determine the profit 'y' when 'x' cookies are sold?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up constant and coefficient in a worded substitution problem

ConstructName: Find missing side lengths in a right-angled triangle using the Cosine (cos) ratio
QuestionText: Find the length of side q in the given triangle: ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 45 degrees, the hypotenuse is 10cm and the side adjacent to this is q.]()
MisconceptionName: Does not find the angle being asked

ConstructName: Enlarging 2D shapes using negative scale factors with the origin (0, 0) as the centre of enlargement
