ConstructName: Sampling and Statistical Inference with a focus on bias sampling methods
QuestionText: A plant biologist wants to estimate the average height of the flowers grown in a garden where there are two colors - red (R) and blue (B), with R flowers mostly at the garden entrance (E) while the B flowers are mostly at the back (B). Which method would be most likely to produce an unbiased estimate of the average height of all flowers in the garden?
AnswerAText: Systematic sampling every alternate row and column throughout the garden
AnswerBText: Collecting random flowers you encounter walking straight down the middle path of the garden
MisconceptionName: Believes any sample gives an equal chance of selection

ConstructName: Applies trigonometric concepts to solve 2D problems involving non-right-angled triangles using the sine rule
QuestionText: In triangle JKL, angle K is 55°, angle L is 93°, and side KL is 12cm. What is the length of JK ? Note: round your answer to the nearest whole number. ![A triangle labelled KLJ, with the angle K labelled 55 degrees, the angle L labelled 93 and the side KL is 12cm.]()
MisconceptionName: Forgets to include a marked right angle when performing angle calculations

ConstructName: Evaluate the mean from a grouped discrete data set
QuestionText:
A set of exam scores is given in the following grouped frequency table. What is an estimate of the mean score of the class?

| Score Group  | Frequency | Mid-point |
|--------------|-----------|-----------|
| 0-49         | 3         | 25        |
| 50-69        | 2         | 60        |
| 70-89        | 4         | 80        |
| 90-100       | 1         | 95        |
MisconceptionName: Believes that Mid-point x Frequency in a grouped frequency table gives an accurate total, rather than an estimate.

ConstructName: Calculate the gradient of a straight line from two points
QuestionText: A line passes through the points (2, 3) and (6, 7). What is the gradient of the line?
MisconceptionName: Does not know how to find the gradient of a straight line from two points

ConstructName: Determine if a data set is discrete or continuous
QuestionText: What type of data is the height of students in a class, which can take any value within a certain range?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up discrete and continuous data types

ConstructName: Analyze the effect of data management decisions on inferences made from linear regression equations
QuestionText: A study showed a negative correlation between the hours of sleep a person gets each night and their body mass index (BMI). A data analyst creates a linear regression equation to model the relationship and then adds an outlier to the data set, shifting the equation so that the line now shows a slightly positive slope. A person who has not seen the original data uses the new equation to make an inference about the relationship between hours of sleep and BMI. What error should this person be concerned about in their inference?
AnswerAText: Their inference may be too optimistic about the beneficial effects of sleep on BMI, and that more sleep may actually lead to higher BMI.
AnswerBText: Their inference may be too pessimistic about the beneficial effects of sleep on BMI, and that more sleep may actually lead to lower BMI
MisconceptionName: Confuses positive and negative correlation

ConstructName: Percentage of an amount calculations
QuestionText: A sweater is on sale for 15% off its original price. If the original price of the sweater was $80, what is the sale price of the sweater?
MisconceptionName: Believes a percentage of a number will be a multiple of the percentage.

ConstructName: Compare and order decimals
QuestionText: Which of the following decimals is the largest: 0.75, 0.058, or 5.8?
MisconceptionName: When ordering decimals, believes the decimal point is not relevant

ConstructName: Linear equations in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText: Find the y-intercept of the line with equation 4x + y = 9
AnswerAText: -4x + y = c, thus the y-intercept when x is 0 is 9
MisconceptionName: Believes the y-intercept of a line is the root of its equation

ConstructName: Probability Sampling Methods
QuestionText: A sample of 50 students is randomly selected from 500 students in a school for a school survey. If it costs $200 to conduct an interview with one student, what will be the cost of the study for every student to be surveyed with an equal chance of selection and the chosen number was selected 10 times less (500->50 students)?
AnswerAText: $200 * 10 * 50 / 10, or simply $10,000, spent 10 times less to maintain equal chance of selection
MisconceptionName: Believes data implies equal chance of selection

ConstructName: Population estimation using the capture-recapture method
QuestionText: In a wildlife conservation study, 50 birds are marked with tags and released. The next day, 30 more birds are caught, 10 of which have tags. Estimate the total population using the capture-recapture method.
MisconceptionName: When using the capture-recapture method, believes the number caught second (30) is the numerator and the number marked second (10) is the denominator

ConstructName: Multiply decimals
MisconceptionName: When multiplying decimals, multiplies rather than divides when reinserting the decimal.

ConstructName: Visualising 3D objects from 2D plans and elevations
QuestionText: A building has a plan view, front elevation, and side elevation as shown. What will the front elevation of the building look like if viewed from the opposite side? ![Plan view of a square building, Front elevation of a house with a triangle-shaped roof, Side elevation showing flat front side and a slope on both sides touching at a point at the back]
AnswerAText: The triangle-shaped roof will be on the opposite side to where it appears in the given front elevation.
AnswerBText: The front elevation will be completely the same with the triangle-shaped roof on the same side.
MisconceptionName: Struggles to visualise how an object will look in 3D when given a plan view, front and side elevation

ConstructName: Identify and explain key measures of a data set, including lower quartile (Q1) and interpret their meaning in context
QuestionText: What is the lower quartile of the following marks in Maths: 52, 60, 61, 63, 65, 66, 69, 72, 73. First, arrange the data set in order and find Q1.
MisconceptionName: Believes the lower quartile is the lowest value in a list

ConstructName: Calculate the product of rational expressions with reciprocals of monomials
QuestionText: \( 2x \) multiplied by the reciprocal of \( -4x \) equals what?
MisconceptionName: Believes that reciprocals are undefined for negative numbers

ConstructName: Converting between milliliters (mL) and liters (L) in the metric system
QuestionText: A water bottle holds 0.85 liters of water. How many milliliters does the water bottle hold?
MisconceptionName: Believes they add the conversion factor when converting between units

ConstructName: Analyze frequency distribution using histograms
QuestionText: A histogram shows the daily number of cars sold in a week, the class width is 5 and the frequency density of the range is between 20-24 is 3. What is the number of cars sold between 20-24?
MisconceptionName: Believes class width divided by frequency density gives frequency in a histogram

ConstructName: Calculating the number of edges on a 3D shape
QuestionText: A garden ornament is in the shape of a rectangular prism. If a cross-section of the ornament, parallel to the base, is a rectangle with 4 edges, how many edges does the entire garden ornament have?
MisconceptionName: Believes the number of edges on a 3D shape match those of the 2D cross section

ConstructName: Multiplication of two-digit numbers
QuestionText: A bookshelf has 16 shelves. Each shelf holds 9 boxes. How many boxes are there in total?
MisconceptionName: Believes even numbers can have odd multiples

ConstructName: Solving problems that require the use of enlargement and scale factor in similar shapes
QuestionText: The given shape has sides of 4cm, 6cm. It's enlarged to create a new shape with sides of 8cm and 12cm and then enlarged again to create a new shape with a side length of x. What is the length of x?
MisconceptionName: Thinks the scale factor is found by adding the lengths of two corresponding sides together

ConstructName: Tell the time in 12-hour format with the correct use of "to" and "past" in verbal time expressions
QuestionText: What is the time 42 minutes after 10:18?
MisconceptionName: Mixes up the words “to” and “past” when telling the time

ConstructName: Understand independent and mutually exclusive events
QuestionText: In a game, a player wins by spinning a wheel that has 8 sections, where 2 sections have the word "Win" and 6 sections have the word "Lose". What is the probability that the player will spin the wheel and get a "Win" and then select a red marble from a bag with 3 red marbles and 7 blue marbles?
MisconceptionName: Confuses dependent and mutually exclusive events

ConstructName: Measure angles using a protractor
QuestionText: Measure the size of angle \( ABC \) in the given diagram. ![A diagram of a protractor with one side of the angle at 20, the other at 80 on the inner scale]
MisconceptionName: Does not know protractor should be positioned with one side of the angle at 0

ConstructName: Identify angles in a quadrilateral
QuestionText: In a quadrilateral with interior angles of 100°, 140°, x°, and 50°, what is the value of x?
MisconceptionName: Uses angles on a straight line in the wrong context

ConstructName: Factorising quadratic expressions of the form ax^2 + bx + c
QuestionText: Factorise the quadratic expression x^2 + 7x + 10
MisconceptionName: Believes that when factorising a quadratic with a coefficient of x squared, the two constants in the brackets still add to give the coefficient of x

ConstructName: Writing a recurring decimal as a fraction
QuestionText: Write 3.9 recurring as a fraction
MisconceptionName: Confuses the lower bound and upper bound, and writes the lower bound as a value that would end in recurring 9's, for example

ConstructName: Graphs of linear equations in the form y = mx + c
QuestionText: What is the y-intercept of the line described by the equation y = 2x + 5?
MisconceptionName: Believes that y = m + cx is the equation of a straight line

ConstructName: Apply the multiplication property of equality to solve linear equations
QuestionText: Solve the equation for \( x \), \( 2x = 6 \), by dividing both sides by 2 and then doubling the result.
AnswerAText: \( 2x = 6 \) divided by 2 is \( x = 3 \), multiplying by 2 on both sides is unnecessary and does not change the result, therefore \( x = 3 \)
AnswerBText: \( 2x = 6 \) divided by 2 is \( x = 3 \), multiplying by 2 on both sides results in \( x = 2 \times 3 \),  the answer should be multiplied by 2 because when multiplied it equals to one of the factors which remains as 1, so the final answer is 6.
MisconceptionName: When multiplying by 1 gives an answer of 1 (for a number other than 1)

ConstructName: Truncating method for estimating limits of accuracy of results obtained from measurements with some error
QuestionText: A machine produces objects with the length as 4.563. Truncate 4.563 to 1 decimal place. Give the limits for the lower and upper bounds for this truncated length.
AnswerAText: The lower bound: 4.563, the upper bound: 4.566
AnswerBText: The lower bound: 4.5625, the upper bound: 4.5635
MisconceptionName: Thinks that the lower and upper bound for a truncated number can be found in the same way as when it has been rounded

ConstructName: Finding a fraction of a quantity using fractions
QuestionText: Find 1/2 of 3/4 of a bookshelf's total books, if the bookshelf has 432 books.
MisconceptionName: When finding a fraction of a fraction, divided by the whole fraction instead of the denominator

ConstructName: Rounding numbers and quantities to a specific number of significant figures in various contexts
QuestionText: Round the number 45.678 to 1 significant figure.
MisconceptionName: Believes rounding to 1 significant figure means rounding to the nearest integer, regardless of the value of the number

ConstructName: Interpret and draw conclusions from weighted mean and standard deviation
QuestionText: A school recorded the number of books read by students in a month, with the following data: 2 books - 100 students, 5 books - 50 students, and 8 books - 20 students. What is the median number of books read?
MisconceptionName: Believes the median is the middle category in a table, ignoring the frequencies

ConstructName: Find the midpoint of grouped data when the data is discrete
QuestionText: A list of students' ages is grouped into ranges: 13-15 (5 students), 16-18 (3 students), 19-21 (4 students), and 24-27 (2 students). What is the midpoint of this data set?
AnswerAText: Since there are a odd number of total students (5 + 3 + 4 + 2 = 14 students), the middle student would be the 7th (average age if we assume equal spacing of students within each group), assuming an even distribution within each group and no exact age given, we can guess the 7th is somewhat between the group's [16-18] mid (17) and [13-15]'s upper bound. Using this assumption and given [13-15] has only 5, and assuming a regular age dist thus assuming even spacing: 13.2+ 2*(18-13)/2 = 16 and it is more precisely: (13+14+15) + 14 + (16 + 16 + 17 + 18)/4= 18. Because there are more students bellow 17, our median value would then have to be even closer to the (16-18)-group, this is somewhat: (18+ 4*(17+16) + 14+15) /7 and we know this must be below (18 +16)/2: 17 so, in between we guess something below the midpoint value 17 but above 16 value of this group at around ~17, so the median would be mostly contained between the second range [16-18] and can be calculated, most likely using more correct age dist and taking into account the other groups to find medians around that midpoint average and would thus calculate this 'assumed mid range', around the [16-18]-group so midpoint approximately ~17 years old.
MisconceptionName: Believes the midpoint of grouped data is equivalent to the group width

ConstructName: Apply the concept of arithmetic sequences to real-world problems
QuestionText: A person invests in two savings plans. Plan A increases her savings by $150 each year and starts with an initial investment of $1000. Plan B starts at $2000 but only increases the savings by $100 in the first year and then by $250 in the second year. However, for subsequent years Plan B actually has a steady increase from the amount it was increased in the previous year.  What type of sequence best describes the yearly increases for Plan B, this example year 1 increase of 100 applies for year one, year 2 increase of 250 applies for year two and then a third year increase of 250+150.
AnswerAText: An arithmetic sequence with a first difference of 150 for years after the second year, the first 2 terms being from the series described in the question
AnswerBText: An arithmetic sequence with a common second difference of 0 since the increase for years after the second is always 150
MisconceptionName: Believes an arithmetic sequence can have a common second difference rather than first difference

ConstructName: Organizing the possible outcomes of a two-stage chance experiment using a tree diagram

ConstructName: Statistics and data analysis - Identifying outliers
QuestionText: Find the outlier in this data set of exam scores: 50, 70, 55, 23, 65, 75, 68, 60. Note that outliers are values that fall significantly outside the range of the main data.
AnswerAText: 23 is not considered an outlier since it's close to the range of other scores, however in the context of scores it might be low but in a set with this data it isn't so the outlier isn't clearly defined.  However in this range 23 does stand out more and since the rest of this list contains mostly numbers above 50 we will review 23 as the likely choice for an outlier in this group  but even more accurately we don't have a clear outlier. A more outlying number not on this list would be needed for a very valid outlier for this list.
MisconceptionName: Believes an outlier has to be a whole number

ConstructName: Evaluating and comparing mental calculations, estimates and exact calculations for whole number multiplications
QuestionText: A recipe for cookies calls for 24 packets of sugar, with each packet weighing 35 grams. A shopkeeper has 4 boxes of sugar packets that each contain 200 packets. Estimate the total weight of the packets the shopkeeper has in kilograms. Is 28kg a good estimate? Why or why not?
AnswerAText: No. Although it is close, using 30g per packet (underestimate) and dividing by 1000 gives 24 which doesn't match the shopkeeper's weight in kg nearly as 24 which is larger, and rounding would make this higher than 30, since the under value will undervalue the the total.
AnswerBText: Yes. Since using 40g per packet (overestimate) results in the same amount of packets needed or more, since it causes the amount required to be lower and provides less total packets needed. With the 40 grams it provides lower packet counts and matches up with provided store packets when using numbers that match stores exact count. Dividing the product of this approximation by 1000 gives a final result close to 28 kg so this estimate is good.
MisconceptionName: Cannot evaluate if an estimate is an underestimate or overestimate

ConstructName: Find the perimeter of a sector given its radius and central angle.
